awd_abstract_narration:
This social computing research will build a scientific foundation for distributed analogical innovation that integrates cognitive science, social science, design, and computer science. The results will contribute back to theory in these source disciplines as well, including theories of analogy, coordination, distributed innovation, scientific discovery, crowdsourcing, and collective intelligence. Innovation in science and technology is often driven by analogy, and opportunities for finding fruitful analogies are exploding with the increased online availability of repositories of ideas ranging from scientific papers to product ideas to the diverse text and video resources.  However, our ability to process this deluge of information to find and use analogies is severely bottlenecked by individual cognitive limits, as the speed and capacity with which individuals can learn and explore new domains have not kept up with the rapid growth in online information from which analogies can be discovered. Furthermore, people are hampered by cognitive biases that prevent them from seeing and applying important parallels to solve comparable problems in different domains. Instead of relying on a single individual to find and apply an analogy, this research will develop methods for distributing analogical processing across multiple individuals. The development of improved innovation processes could accelerate technological innovation and scientific discovery, with corresponding benefits to the economy and to science.

The general approach will be to conduct empirical studies to rigorously explore and characterize the benefits and limitations of distributed analogical innovation, and then to generalize these findings in the context of two real-world innovation communities.  Distributing innovation tasks to different individuals could have a number of significant advantages. First, increasing the number of people involved could increase the capacity to find and use analogies across many domains. Second, changing the representations of problems and solutions could help innovators see the relevance of solutions from distant domains and reduce problems with fixation, in which people are overly influenced by surface features. Third, by distributing the steps involved in analogy to different people, alternative innovation paths could be explored effectively in parallel. Fourth, disaggregating the innovation pipeline opens up participation to many more people; one need not be an expert in a problem domain, for example, to find analog solutions in remote domains. Fifth, in contrast to innovation contests that reward only a small number of contest winners, the sequential method to be used in this research allows people to build on each other's work and doesn't waste the labor of the vast majority of participants.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated factors that contribute to the success of distributed innovation processes in real-world R&D contexts as well in controlled laboratory contexts. In terms of intellectual merit, the findings from this project advanced our knowledge on (1) the role of expertise in distributed analogical innovation processes, (2) ways to apply distributed analogical innovation processes to problems with multiple constraints, and (3) the benefits and limitations of distributed innovation processes in online contest communities. In terms of broader impact, the outcomes of this project have been transferred to several collaborating organizations, including the Innovation Research Interchange, Bosch, and Conservation X Labs, and influenced their innovation practices as well as several actual innovation contests. Below, we summarize the major research activities and findings from each year across the life of this project/award. 


During the first two years of this project, we investigated the role of expertise in distributed analogical innovation processes, specifically in the context of complex R&D problem solving. To do this, we conducted a series of field experiments with the Innovation Research Interchange (a global non-profit consortium of R&D professionals from a diverse range of industrial companies and governmental agencies), in which we explored whether non-expert crowd workers could help expert R&D practitioners be more creative and diverse in developing solutions to real-world problems.  We found that inspirations provided by crowd workers could help R&D experts explore additional novel parts of the design space than they did on their own. However, experts were crucial in actually integrating those inspirations into high quality solutions, suggesting that a hybrid organization of experts and crowds might provide the benefits of both diversity and experience. Replicating this work in situ at a partner R&D lab, we found that R&D experts used the inspirations to explore design spaces that they wouldn’t have explored on their own, and did so by adapting the high level ideas behind the inspiration, rather than taking it wholesale. Together, these results suggest new opportunities for combining the advantages of non-expert crowds and R&D experts to reap the benefits of distributed analogical innovation in real world R&D processes.


During the third year of this project, we investigated potential mechanisms underlying the successful application of distributed analogical innovation processes to problems with multiple constraints, which are more representative of the complexity of problems in the world today. To do this, we conducted a series of rigorously controlled online experiments with crowdworkers on Amazon Mechanical Turk, in which we manipulated the number of problem constraints as well as the nature of problem constraints that workers had to solve at once. We found that solving two constraints at a time led to more creative solutions than solving four constraints at a time, possibly because it reduced cognitive load and allowed more focused investment on each constraint. Additionally, solving two conflicting constraints at a time led to more creative solutions than solving two non-conflicting constraints at a time, possibly because it required more adaptation and integration of analogical inspirations. These findings suggest potential ways of optimizing distributed analogical innovation processes to solve problems with multiple constraints. 


During the fourth year of this project, we leveraged a new opportunity to partner with an open innovation platform hosted by the environment nonprofit Conservation X Labs to investigate strategies for improving the success of collaborations in distributed innovation settings more broadly. Specifically, we conducted a series of randomized field trials to test the effects of peer advising on participant engagement and solution quality in online innovation contests. We found that peer advising can effectively engage a broad range of contest community members, including losers, winners, active competitors, newcomers, and oldtimers to exchange benefits that are useful to both feedback providers and receivers (i.e., networking, learning from other project teams, finding useful resources for projects, etc.). In addition, we identified ways of implementing peer advising in online innovation contests to boost its effectiveness. In particular, we found that explicitly matching peers with similar projects can boost the quantity of engagement as well as peer advisors’ perceptions of value to project teams (compared to randomly matching peers). We identified two specific challenges (i.e., improving matching and reducing fixation) that can guide the design of future peer advising programs towards better outcomes for a broader range of participants in contest communities. All together, these findings suggest potential ways of optimizing how peer collaboration processes are structured to facilitate the benefits of distributed innovation in real-world contexts.
